greeting: Greetings from The On-Line Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences! http://oeis.org/

results.name: a(n) = the least k >= 1 for which the Jacobi symbol J(k,2n+1) is not +1 (thus is either 0 or -1).
comment: If we instead list the least k >= 1, for which Jacobi symbol J(k,2n+1) is 0, we get A090368.

It is easy to see that every term is prime. Because the Jacobi symbol is multiplicative as J(ab,m) = J(a,m)*J(b,m) and if for every index i>=1 and < x, J(i,m)=1, then if J(x,m) is 0 or -1, x cannot be composite (say y*z, with both y and z less than x), as then either J(y,m) or J(z,m) would be non-one, which contradicts our assumption that x is the first index where non-one value appears. Thus x must be prime.
link: Indranil Ghosh and A.H.M. Smeets, Table of n, a(n) for n = 1..20000 (first 1000 terms from Indranil Ghosh)
program: (PARI) A112046(n) = for(i=1, (2*n), if((kronecker(i, (n+n+1)) < 1), return(i))); \\ _Antti Karttunen_, May 26 2017
from sympy import jacobi_symbol as J
print([a(n) for n in range(1, 103)]) # _Indranil Ghosh_, May 11 2017
xref: Bisections: A112047, A112048, and their difference: A112053.
results.author: _Antti Karttunen_, Aug 27 2005
